description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Latvia
March 16th, 2020
As of March 16, 2020, the government of Latvia announced that preschools and childcare facilities will only be available for children whose parents may prove that the child and family have not been abroad and have not been in contact with Covid-19 patients or their contacts during the last 14 days. Parents must also state in this certificate that it is not possible to provide childcare in any other way.

description:
Latvia
April 30th 2020
The Ministry of Education and Science informs that for 9th grade students, state examinations are canceled, except for the examination in the Latvian language in minority education programs.

 For students who wish to take it, the written part of the exam will take place on June 10, and the oral part - on June 10 and 11. For students who, for justified reasons, are unable to take the exam on time and who wish to take it, the exam will take place on 2 July.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with no conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Latvia
April 30th 2020

state examinations for the acquisition of general secondary education (grades 12) will take place in the following order.

Compulsory centralized examinations:
in one foreign language of your choice (English part on June 2, oral part on June 2, 3 and 4; German article and oral part on June 3; Russian part on June 4, oral part 4 and 5 June, in French for written and oral submissions on 5 June); written exam in Latvian - on June 9; written exam in mathematics - June 12.

List of centralized examinations in the subject chosen by the student:
Written exam in the history of Latvia and the world - June 15; in chemistry (written) - June 17; in Biology (written) - June 19; in physics (written) - on June 26;

List of exams in the subject chosen by the student:
in geography (written) - June 29; in economics (in writing) - on July 1; in minority language and literature (Russian) in minority education programs (in writing) - on July 3. part of articles in informatics - on July 6, practical part - on July 6 and 7.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with no conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 30th Latvia decided to cancel 9th grader exams for this school year and reduce number of exams for 12th school grade. UPDATE: On April 30th Lativa decided to keep schools closed. All state tests for 9th graders in Latvia have been cancelled for this school year. The number of compulsory tests for 12th graders has been reduced. Now compulsory exams include only one foreign language exam, Latvian language exam and mathematics exam.

description:
Latvia 
May 2020
The Latvian government provided a list of acceptable, cautious, and do nots for institutions.
This included a list for schools, on the list of do nots were
There must be no training in person
 - Exams canceled for 9th grade
 - Not to be organized competition
 - Do not organize a child interest education face-to-face classes
 - Do not organize a child camps
 - The school may not organize graduation party

Latvia 
May 2020
The Latvian government provided a list of acceptable, cautious, and do nots for institutions.
This included a list for schools, on the list of do nots were
There must be no training in person
 - Exams canceled for 9th grade
 - Not to be organized competition

description:
Latvia 
May 2020
The Latvian government provided a list of acceptable, cautious, and do nots for institutions.
This included a list for schools, on the list of do nots were
There must be no training in person
 - Exams canceled for 9th grade
 - Not to be organized competition
 - Do not organize a child interest education face-to-face classes
 - Do not organize a child camps
 - The school may not organize graduation party UPDATE: While prior the government had listed a series of do's and don't for schools during the pandemic, The government as of June 9th 2020 enlisted new guidelines for schools and camps. These guidelines allow, among other things, for examinations to take place so long as corona measures are taken into consideration.
These policies are in effect until August 31st

description:
Latvia
August 25th 2020
In order to be able to better comply with the necessary epidemiological safety precautions during lunch when resuming full-time education in schools, the government decided today, 25 August, to allow more flexibility for caterers by providing children with packed lunches.


This variation will be available to caterers until the end of this year.

July 28th 2020

description:
Latvia
September 1st, 2020
The government rereleased guidlines for schools on COVID safety. 

From 1 September, schools must organize (A) face-to-face training. For the safe organization of the flow of people, they can take place (B) partially remotely. If a case of Covid-19 is detected in a school, there should be a plan to organize the training (C) completely remotely according to the of recommendations of the Ministry Education and Science .
- In schools, lunch breaks may be shorter than 30 minutes 
Additionally 

However, Kindergartens may be fully operational subject to epidemiological safety requirements

description:
Latvia
September 20th 2020

Taking into account the latest epidemiological information about local outbreaks of Covid-19 in Kuldiga and Daugavpils, the government decided today, September 30, to impose stricter precautionary measures for Covid-19 in both cities. Restrictions are currently set for October 1-14.

As previously pointed out by epidemiologists, with the emergence of local outbreaks in specific locations, it is not necessary to impose restrictions throughout the country, but the situation can be assessed at the municipal level. Thus, until October 14, additional restrictions are set in two cities - Daugavpils and Kuldiga:

    the acquisition of amateur art and interest and professional education in person (including training, competitions and rehearsals) may not take place, also for adults;
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Full remote/distance learning (e.g. All teachers must tele-teach.)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

October 27th, 2020
On October 27th, 2020, the Latvian Cabinet of Ministers decided to extend duration of distance learning. Latvia
November 27th, 2020
In Latvian municipalities, Daugavpils, Baldone, Krāslava, Salacgrīva, Aknīste, Varakļāni, Mārupe, Mālpils, Smiltene, Garkalne, Limbaži and Salaspils, the government will introduce more restrictive measures which are that in these regions, starting November 27, 2020: pupils of grades 5-12 will learn remotely; vocational and higher education will be remote; professional development/adult education courses and classes will not take place.

UPDATE: The original policy allowed from some in class participation, the current still allows for it but with heavier restrictions

In the field of education, from 30 November[2020]:

    In schools, each child must have an area of ​​at least three square meters from the classroom. Educators should use mouth and nose pads both during and between learning sessions.
    Higher education and vocational training workshops that cannot be carried out remotely may not exceed 10 people per group.

description:
Latvia
December 1st, 2020
On Tuesday, December 1, 2020, in a decision on the extension of the Emergency, the Cabinet of Ministers decided to simplify security measures, facilitating the control of the spread of Covid-19 infection. The process of higher education, vocational education, and adult continuing and non-formal education can only take place remotely. On the other hand, practical skills that cannot be acquired remotely can be acquired in person only individually - one teacher with one student.

The practical parts of interest education can only take place in person. Attempts by choirs and wind ensembles are not allowed in person.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

update_level_var: [compliance]  of policy strengthening ; timing of policy strengthening
description:
From October 26 to November 15, higher education study programs in Latvia will takes place remotely only, except for the acquisition of the practical and clinical practice, e.g. among student doctors. UPDATE: The prior policy was set to end December 31st 2020
Now...
Today, on 17 December [2020], the government decided to make amendments to Cabinet of Ministers Order No. 655 "Regarding Declaration of the Emergency Situation", strengthening safety measures from 21 December to 11 January.
In education:

    Winter holidays will be extended for 1 week until 8 January for pupils from grade 1 to grade 6.
    There will be no practical classes in person (also not individually). Also in professional and higher education, various courses, etc. classes may only take place remotely. The exception is clinical training in residency.
    Interest-related education and various practices can take place only remotely.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
institution_status: Higher education institutions closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Latvia
January 7th, 2021
On January 7th, 2021, the Latvian Government announced new restrictions for schools that will take place until 25th January: until January 22, pupils of 1 - 4. grades will have an extended winter break, and pupils of 5-12 grades will study online from 11 January, clinical internships at the residency and practical classes for medical students of the 6th year of study to provide support to hospitals may take place in person, special educational institutions and kindergartens will operate in person, other practical classes (also individually) are possible only remotely. description:
Latvia
September 1st, 2020
The government rereleased guidlines for schools on COVID safety. 

From 1 September, schools must organize (A) face-to-face training. For the safe organization of the flow of people, they can take place (B) partially remotely. If a case of Covid-19 is detected in a school, there should be a plan to organize the training (C) completely remotely according to the of recommendations of the Ministry Education and Science .
- In schools, lunch breaks may be shorter than 30 minutes 
Additionally 

However, Kindergartens may be fully operational subject to epidemiological safety requirements UPDATE: Whereas in the original policy there was a code to follow to determine whether a school should be closed, full remote, or opened; and while other policies dictated various grade ranges switching to remote learning at different points, now on January 21st 2020 the government has decided ALL grades will be remote learning.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Number of people on the school premises are limited (e.g. only 50 people allowed on school premises),Regular cleaning and sanitary procedures applied to classrooms (e.g. classrooms must be aired out after each class),Negative COVID-19 Test,Full remote/distance learning (e.g. All teachers must tele-teach.),Partial remote/distance learning  (e.g. Teachers with certain health conditions can tele-teach)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

update_level_var: [compliance] of policy relaxing ; timing of policy relaxing
description:
Latvia
September 1st, 2020
The government rereleased guidlines for schools on COVID safety. 

From 1 September, schools must organize (A) face-to-face training. For the safe organization of the flow of people, they can take place (B) partially remotely. If a case of Covid-19 is detected in a school, there should be a plan to organize the training (C) completely remotely according to the of recommendations of the Ministry Education and Science .
- In schools, lunch breaks may be shorter than 30 minutes 
Additionally 

However, Kindergartens may be fully operational subject to epidemiological safety requirements UPDATE: Whereas earlier, the policy was extended until April 6th 2021, now the policy is returning to its routes and is based per the city.

Consequently, the Cabinet of Ministers has conceptually agreed on a regional approach in the field of education. A detailed decision should be made at the meeting of 18 February [2021], however, it is planned that local governments, where the cumulative number of new infections does not exceed 200 for a two-week period, may decide to resume full-time education for 1st-4th year students. At the same time, schools must meet a number of epidemiological safety requirements.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions

description:
Latvia
February 24th 2021
In his resolution, K. Kariņš instructed the Ministry of Welfare to urgently identify the situation with the necessary computer equipment, Internet in state and municipal out-of-home care institutions and in cooperation with the Ministry of Education and Science to ensure that children in all out-of-home care institutions have full participation in distance learning.

The Ministry of Welfare, in cooperation with the Ministry of Health and local governments, is also tasked with ensuring that children in out-of-home care have access to timely and appropriate psychological support.

description:
Latvia
February 26th, 2021
At the meeting of the Ministry of Culture on Friday, February 26, 2021, the Latvian government decided to allow individual consultations in the acquisition of vocational education programs, observing the safety requirements set by epidemiologists. The consultation may last for a maximum of 40 minutes, during which the teacher and the learner use a mouth and nose cover and keep a distance of two meters.

September 1st, 2020
The government rereleased guidlines for schools on COVID safety. 

From 1 September, schools must organize (A) face-to-face training. For the safe organization of the flow of people, they can take place (B) partially remotely. If a case of Covid-19 is detected in a school, there should be a plan to organize the training (C) completely remotely according to the of recommendations of the Ministry Education and Science .
- In schools, lunch breaks may be shorter than 30 minutes 
Additionally 

However, Kindergartens may be fully operational subject to epidemiological safety requirements UPDATE: The prior policy allowed for some schools to open early when numbers of infection were low.
Now, From March 16 [2021], work will continue in pre-school education institutions, admitting only those children whose parents have to work full-time, as well as those whose nature of work makes it impossible to work remotely and provide childcare at the same time. In pre-school education, staff should use mouth and nose pads properly during and outside the learning process.

In order to protect the health of both employees and children, it is planned that a pre-school Covid-19 test is performed on pre-school employees.

In lengthy discussions, the Cabinet of Ministers cautiously decided to allow up to five formal education sessions and up to two non-formal education sessions per week for a group of up to 20 people per year in the municipalities where the 14-day cumulative morbidity rate per 100,000 people does not exceed 250. The duration of one lesson does not exceed 40 minutes.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Number of people on the school premises are limited (e.g. only 50 people allowed on school premises),Regular cleaning and sanitary procedures applied to classrooms (e.g. classrooms must be aired out after each class),Negative COVID-19 Test,Full remote/distance learning (e.g. All teachers must tele-teach.),Partial remote/distance learning  (e.g. Teachers with certain health conditions can tele-teach)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Latvia
February 18th, 2021
On 18 February 2021, supporting the principle of full-time study regions proposed by the Ministry of Education and Science, it was agreed that it will be possible to resume face-to-face training in those municipalities where the incidence of Covid-19 is less than 200 patients per 100,000 population. Conditions are: students from grade 1 must wear masks, schools provide regular ventilation of the premises, distance between classes, non-overlapping classes, disinfection measures, and an algorithm developed by the Health Inspectorate. Covid-19 testing is mandatory for on-site staff. Educators in high-risk groups - with chronic illnesses and seniors from the age of 60 - can work remotely until a vaccination against Covid-19 is started, in agreement with the head of the educational institution.

description:
Latvia
September 1st, 2020
The government rereleased guidlines for schools on COVID safety. 

From 1 September, schools must organize (A) face-to-face training. For the safe organization of the flow of people, they can take place (B) partially remotely. If a case of Covid-19 is detected in a school, there should be a plan to organize the training (C) completely remotely according to the of recommendations of the Ministry Education and Science .
- In schools, lunch breaks may be shorter than 30 minutes 
Additionally 

However, Kindergartens may be fully operational subject to epidemiological safety requirements UPDATE: Whereas prior, classes for preschool could operate under certain circumstances and some schools could open when under the 250/100,000 threshold now...

Kindergartens will continue to operate on-site after April 7[2021]. To reduce the risk of Covid-19 spread, workers should adhere to epidemiological safety requirements, including the use of mouth and nose pads. Kindergarten staff will continue to be tested once a week.

At other levels of education, learning is provided remotely, but with a few exceptions, with education as one of the government's priorities and children's psycho-emotional health. From April 7, in municipalities where the two-week morbidity rate per 100,000 people does not exceed 200, face-to-face training can be organized for 1-6. and 12th grade students. 7.-11. For pupils in the classroom, full-time studies may take place on a rotating basis so that the classes do not overlap in the educational establishment. In order to resume full-time studies, the educational institution must provide epidemiological requirements and weekly testing of staff.

Individual face-to-face counseling will still be available throughout Latvia for 12th grade students and those at risk of dropping out, and for those who have to take state examinations in the first half of 2021. On-site consultations take place only at the individual invitation of the teacher in accordance with the epidemiological safety procedure. The consultation time should not exceed 40 minutes.

In municipalities where the number of new Covid-19 infections per 100,000 inhabitants exceeds 200 in two weeks, 12th grade students will be able to attend on-site training no more than two days a week in the subjects where the centralized examinations are taken. Up to 5 face-to-face classes per week can be organized for students of other classes in these municipalities, up to a maximum of 10 people per group.

From April 7, it will be possible to organize face-to-face classes for groups of up to 10 people in vocational education, interest education and artistic collectives

description:
Latvia
April 29th, 2021
On  April 29, 2021 the Latvian government approved amendments for final examination for obtaining general secondary education which will take place in person. Exams for obtaining general secondary education will be held starting on May 11 2021, however, their number has been reduced. In order to obtain a certificate of general secondary education this year and also next year, students will not necessarily have to take the fourth or optional exam. Professional qualification exams are planned for June 2021(participants during this time will be no more than 10).
Regulations are as follows: testing must be carried out(only those testing negative may attend), distance and hygiene requirements must be observed, as well as personal protective equipment must be used by everyone during the exams, including mouth and nose covers. No more than 25 students may be present in one exam room, but the presence of up to 40 students is allowed in an appropriately sized school hall.

description:
Latvia 
May 15th, 2021
On May 15th 2021, the Latvian government approved amendments for conducting entrance exams in general education institutions. The amendments clarify how entrance exams for admission to formal education programs at the basic and secondary education level may take place in person. When organizing the entrance exam, there may be no more than 10 people in one group, those present in and outside the exam room use mouth and nose covers and keep a distance of two meters. For the purpose of additional security, the amendments also provide for the conduct of Covid-19 tests. In order to participate in the entrance exam in person, the Covid-19 test must be taken within the last 72 hours before the entrance exam. The Covid-19 test may not be performed if a person can documentally prove that they have been infected with SARS CoV-2 in the last three months and no longer pose a risk of infection to others. Also, the Covid-19 test is not carried out by persons who can document that they have been fully vaccinated against the Covid-19 infection.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

In order to participate in the entrance exam in person, the Covid-19 test must be taken within the last 72 hours before the entrance exam. The Covid-19 test may not be performed if a person can documentally prove that they have been infected with SARS CoV-2 in the last three months and no longer pose a risk of infection to others. Also, the Covid-19 test is not carried out by persons who can document that they have been fully vaccinated against the Covid-19 infection.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Latvia
September 1st, 2020
The government rereleased guidlines for schools on COVID safety. 

From 1 September, schools must organize (A) face-to-face training. For the safe organization of the flow of people, they can take place (B) partially remotely. If a case of Covid-19 is detected in a school, there should be a plan to organize the training (C) completely remotely according to the of recommendations of the Ministry Education and Science .
- In schools, lunch breaks may be shorter than 30 minutes 
Additionally 

However, Kindergartens may be fully operational subject to epidemiological safety requirements UPDATE: Whereas prior classes were allowed to take place in select locations that fell below the infection rate of 200/100,000, now June 2nd 2021,
Education

In order to implement the mandatory requirement for maintaining the qualification and to ensure the possibility to acquire the practical part of continuing professional education programs, qualification practice, passing the professional qualification examinations, as well as the practical part of professional development programs, groups of up to 10 people At least 3 m premises must be ensured in the training premises 2 per person, 2 m distance between persons and ventilation of the . Learners and teachers should use face fees. Participation in face-to-face classes is possible with a negative Covid-19 test result.

At the same time, it should be noted that persons who have been vaccinated or have contracted Covid-19 with a certificate may attend full-time adult vocational training programs in a group of up to 20 people, without complying with the requirements for wearing masks, distance, etc., except ventilation.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

update_level_var: Volume of policy relaxing ; timing of policy strengthening
description:
Latvia closes schools, kindergartens, universities and suspends all kinds of educational activities from March 13 on, online teaching planned UPDATE: Whereas prior all preschools were closed, now as of May 13th, 
The amendments stipulate that in June, July and August 2021, pre-school education programs will be able to be implemented in joint groups of up to 24 children within one educational institution or municipality, strictly observing epidemiological safety measures. In order to prevent unjustified group meetings, the amendments stipulate that children should not be exchanged between groups more than once a month.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description:
Latvia
June 29th, 2021
On June 29, 2021, the Latvian government supported the proposal prepared by the Ministry of Education and Science to allow sports training for students of interest education and vocational education programs also indoors. The proposal to increase the number of people who can be at the outdoor sports competition venue at the same time was also supported. As long as the 14-day cumulative number of Covid-19 cases per 100,000 inhabitants does not exceed 120, 500 people will be able to be at the sports competition venue outdoors at the same time instead of the previous 300. The requirement to comply with a certain m2  will depend on the epidemiological situation - as long as the 14-day cumulative number of Covid-19 cases per 100,000 does not exceed 120, one person will have to provide not 25 m2 , but 15 m2 in the training (lessons) of sports students 2   of the available area, and the requirement of 20% of the maximum possible number of people will not have to be met.
The time of sports training (lesson) may not exceed 90 minutes, changing rooms may not be used, except in public swimming pools, if the filling in the changing rooms does not exceed 25% . Students under the age of 5 may not be involved in sports training (lessons) , except for students in the swimming training program.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
institution_status: Higher education institutions allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Number of people on the school premises are limited (e.g. only 50 people allowed on school premises),Types of people on school premises are limited (e.g. no parents),Regular cleaning and sanitary procedures applied to classrooms (e.g. classrooms must be aired out after each class),Negative COVID-19 Test
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Latvia
November 17th 2020
After medical workers will come customers and employees of social care centers, then people in risk groups.

It is currently planned that a total of more than 800 000 people could be provided with a state-paid vaccine. This number could be higher if the vaccine manufacturers approve Latvia's order.

So far, the National Health Service has entered into an agreement on the supply of vaccines with two vaccine manufacturers — AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson (Janssen). The Minister for Health Ilze Viņķele said that €1.6 million has been paid upfront s so that Latvia can receive these vaccines.

It is likely that there will also be an agreement with another potential manufacturer, Pfizer, and altogether there are 7-8 producers in the ministry's lists.

“Latvia will do everything to make vaccines available,” the minister said.

The Ministry currently forecasts that, following a positive development scenario, the first delivery (according to the schedule for deliveries of “AstraZeneca”) is to take place in the first quarter of next year. The entire volume ordered will not be delivered immediately, but in parts every month.

Accordingly, the Ministry of Health has determined that health care workers would receive the vaccines first, then customers and employees of social care centers and then successively persons aged over 65, people with chronic diseases, employees of operational services and employees of educational establishments.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Purchase of COVID-19 vaccines
type_vac_cat: Johnson & Johnson vaccine (JNJ-78436735 or Ad26.COV2.S; by Johnson & Johnson and Janssen Pharmaceutical)
type_vac_purchase: Preorder with the option of expanding the order
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Latvia
December 1st 2020
On December 1, the Cabinet of Ministers considered the information report prepared by the Ministry of Health on the vaccination strategy against Covid-19.

To date, none of the vaccine manufacturers who have reported on their vaccine research have registered Covid-19 vaccines. However, the Ministry of Health and the responsible authorities are preparing for the vaccine to be registered and available. To date, the National Health Service has entered into vaccine supply agreements with four vaccine manufacturers - AstraZeneca , Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) , BioNTech / Pfizer , CureVac . The need to contract with several vaccine manufacturers is due to the fact that it is currently not possible to predict whether the registration process for all vaccines will be successful. It is also not possible to determine which vaccines will be the most effective, efficient and safe, and it is not known exactly which vaccines will be available the fastest. The volume of vaccines offered by the four vaccine manufacturers could provide an opportunity to vaccinate approximately one million Latvians.

The European Commission recommends that, depending on the situation in each country, priority groups for people to be vaccinated could be considered. Consequently, the Ministry of Health has determined that the vaccines would be given first to health care workers, then to social care center clients and staff, and then to people over the age of 60, people with chronic illne
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description:
Latvia
December 18th 2020
If the European Medicines Agency (EMA) recommends that the vaccine developed by BioNTech and Pfizer be registered on Monday, 21 December, the European Commission (EC) will decide in a few days to grant a marketing authorization valid in all EU and EEA countries. After that, the vaccine can be delivered to all European Union countries at the same time, including Latvia. Thus, on December 28, 10 vaccination offices will start operating in Latvia, where medical staff working with COVID-19 patients and employees of the Emergency Medical Service (NMPD) will be able to receive the vaccine.

All of these dates are subject to change as neither the ESA nor the EC has officially confirmed these dates. Minister of Health Ilze Hänķele emphasizes: “Starting vaccination is not a race for speed. Our priority is to make sure that everyone involved is knowledgeable and ready to go. Let me remind you that there is some information that EU countries will only receive when the ESA recommends that a vaccine be registered. At the same time, we have made every effort to ensure that the Latvian side is ready to receive the vaccine, organize its distribution and offer it to the first group in society, which is currently the most vulnerable - doctors working with COVID-19 patients and NMPD staff. ”

Vaccination with Covid-19 will be voluntary and not mandatory, including for healthcare professionals. Taking into account the gradual introduction of vaccines into the market, th

description:
Latvia
Today, January 8 [2021], the Cabinet of Ministers decided to allocate an additional 23 million euros to allow the Ministry of Health to purchase up to 1,403,000 additional doses of vaccine from vaccine manufacturer BioNTech-Pfizer. This will enable an additional 701,500 people to receive the vaccine in Latvia. The Minister of Health will also be authorized to apply for additional doses of vaccine if needed.

Comprehensive vaccination is our "Baltic way" to freedom from pandemics. I urge doctors to go vaccination in the coming days. Vaccines must not be left in the refrigerator, otherwise we risk not vaccinating those who are ready! ” says Health Minister Daniel Pavluts, who met with GPs and hospital managers today, 8 January, the first day after confirmation.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Latvia 
January 28th 2021

The goal is to vaccinate 70% of Latvia's adult population by the end of the summer

This page was last updated on January 28, 2021

It is planned to vaccinate up to 70% of the Latvian population by the end of the summer, according to the informative report of the Ministry of Health "On the Covid-19 vaccination plan", which was heard today by the Cabinet of Ministers.

Minister of Health Daniels Pavļuts: “The vaccination plan we approved in government today is detailed, digital and flexible. Uncertainty is the only certainty of the time, now we will be ready to act in different situations. Both when there is a delay in the supply of vaccines and when there are a lot of them. ”

The updated vaccination plan is designed to make optimal use of the resources of the vaccination system and to implement a convenient and flexible vaccination process. The plan sets out a number of basic principles:

    the establishment of common lists of vaccinees, which will make it possible to maintain contact between those who have expressed an interest in vaccination and the location of the population in the priority group, as well as vaccination sites,
    the creation of a common calendar and queue to help plan the workload and opening hours of vaccination points and the management of records,
    centralized supply of vaccines and stockpile management,
    unified communication with the population.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Latvia
January 28th 2021
In order to prevent possible risks that Latvia may not receive timely deliveries of vaccines from currently planned but not yet registered manufacturers, the government has delegated to the Ministry of Health to apply for additional doses of Covid-19 from Moderna and two other manufacturers - Novavax and Valneva. with which the European Commission has currently concluded pre-emption agreements.

Thus, Latvia will apply for another 420 thousand doses of “Moderna” vaccines, which are planned to be received in the third and fourth quarters of this year. In turn, it is planned to purchase more than 546 thousand doses of vaccines from Novavax and Valneva.

The government has allocated up to € 14.3 million in contingency funding for the purchase, logistics and provision of vaccines.

description:
Latvia
February 4th 2021
The goal of early application is to effectively plan the workload and capacity of vaccination rooms. Citizens are encouraged not to rush to register their applications during the first days of operation of the site. The first vaccines will be given to those in the priority groups. All other citizens' applications received within one calendar month will be treated equally, on a random basis.

A vaccination hotline will be opened in the near future, which is important for many of our citizens, including some of our seniors. Residents over the age of 60 are also one of the first priority groups to be invited to vaccinate, both those who have applied themselves and those who have been contacted by GPs.

description:
Latvia
February 18th 2021
GPs are joining the Covid-19 vaccination process.

The Ministry of Health invites all residents over the age of 70 who want to be vaccinated against Covid-19, but have not yet applied for their vaccine at www.manavakcina.lv or by calling 8989, to contact their family doctor now.

If the family doctor is also a provider of vaccination services (the family doctor will be able to tell you during the interview), then the family doctor will register for the vaccine, as well as the vaccination process will take place there at the GP's invitation.

If, after calling a family doctor, a resident finds out that his or her family doctor is not a vaccination service provider , then:

    some general practitioners will register, but will pass on information on applications for the organization of the vaccination process;
    other family doctors will invite residents over the age of 70 to call the free vaccination registration phone number 8989 or, if possible, register at www.manavakcina.lv;
    in both cases, the data will be used to contact the population and at some point invite the population to be vaccinated as close as possible to the territory indicated by the population.

description:
Latvia
March 12th 2021

Residents with permanent functional disorders and those who cannot access a medical institution due to medical reasons have the opportunity to apply for out-of-place vaccination at the place of residence.

These residents or their carers are invited to apply for vaccination at the place of residence in two ways:

    calling a family doctor (also a proactive call from the family doctor to the patient)
    by calling 8989 (if the resident has already applied for the vaccine via manavakcina.lv or 8989, then you must contact us again by phone 8989 to indicate the necessity of the trip and the exact address).

description:
Latvia
November 17th 2020
After medical workers will come customers and employees of social care centers, then people in risk groups.

It is currently planned that a total of more than 800 000 people could be provided with a state-paid vaccine. This number could be higher if the vaccine manufacturers approve Latvia's order.

So far, the National Health Service has entered into an agreement on the supply of vaccines with two vaccine manufacturers — AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson (Janssen). The Minister for Health Ilze Viņķele said that €1.6 million has been paid upfront s so that Latvia can receive these vaccines.

It is likely that there will also be an agreement with another potential manufacturer, Pfizer, and altogether there are 7-8 producers in the ministry's lists.

“Latvia will do everything to make vaccines available,” the minister said.

The Ministry currently forecasts that, following a positive development scenario, the first delivery (according to the schedule for deliveries of “AstraZeneca”) is to take place in the first quarter of next year. The entire volume ordered will not be delivered immediately, but in parts every month.

Accordingly, the Ministry of Health has determined that health care workers would receive the vaccines first, then customers and employees of social care centers and then successively persons aged over 65, people with chronic diseases, employees of operational services and employees of educational establishments. UPDATE: Whereas prior on November 17th 2020 there were four vaccines allowed, now on March 16th 2021, following a health scare, Astrazeneca is currently suspended.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

Amendments developed by the Ministry of Health * The regulations of the Cabinet of Ministers envisage the involvement of local governments in organizing the vaccination process in their administrative territory, ensuring vaccination facilities, transmission channels."

description:
Latvia
On Saturday, April 10 [2021], two large-scale vaccination centers will test the “live queue” principle: residents of the currently open priority groups will be vaccinated without prior appointment: seniors over 60 (including the current priority group over 70), residents with chronic diseases, persons living in the same household as severely ill or immunosuppressed children and carers of severely ill persons. Vaccination will be done with the manufacturer's AstraZeneca vaccine.

UPDATE: Whereas the government opened large scale vaccine centers and then on May 10th 2021, they allowed for walk-ins for seniors, now as of may 17th 2021, they will continue this program until May 23rd, using Pfizer/BioNtech in some areas and Janssen being offered the 21 and 22nd.

description:
Latvia
December 1st 2020
On December 1, the Cabinet of Ministers considered the information report prepared by the Ministry of Health on the vaccination strategy against Covid-19.

To date, none of the vaccine manufacturers who have reported on their vaccine research have registered Covid-19 vaccines. However, the Ministry of Health and the responsible authorities are preparing for the vaccine to be registered and available. To date, the National Health Service has entered into vaccine supply agreements with four vaccine manufacturers - AstraZeneca , Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) , BioNTech / Pfizer , CureVac . The need to contract with several vaccine manufacturers is due to the fact that it is currently not possible to predict whether the registration process for all vaccines will be successful. It is also not possible to determine which vaccines will be the most effective, efficient and safe, and it is not known exactly which vaccines will be available the fastest. The volume of vaccines offered by the four vaccine manufacturers could provide an opportunity to vaccinate approximately one million Latvians.

The European Commission recommends that, depending on the situation in each country, priority groups for people to be vaccinated could be considered. Consequently, the Ministry of Health has determined that the vaccines would be given first to health care workers, then to social care center clients and staff, and then to people over the age of 60, people with chronic illne UPDATE: Whereas in December 2020 three Vaccines were approved for usage in the adult population, now as of the 17th of May 2021, 16-17 year olds maye receive Pfizer-BioNTech
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Latvia
Today, on August 17 [2021], the government approved changes to the regulations of the Cabinet of Ministers *, according to which Latvia is provided with the opportunity to complete vaccination against Covid-19 with another manufacturer's vaccine and obtain an interoperable digital Covid-19 certificate.

At the same time, in accordance with the recommendation of the National Council for Immunization, changes have been made to the vaccination manual, which allows the use of a different technology or so-called heterologous vaccination for primary immunization against Covid-19. The decision to stop vaccinating with another manufacturer's vaccine will be made by a doctor or a doctor's assistant in collaboration with the patient. The National Board of Immunization has expressed the view that the use of mixed Covid-19 vaccine technologies for both doses is not inferior to single technology regimens.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Latvia
March 17th, 2020

The government of Latvia announced that international passenger transport through airports, ports, by bus and rail transport will be canceled as of 17 March. 
Also, the movement of persons and vehicles through the airport, port, railway, and road border crossing points at the European Union’s external border, as well as at border crossing points intended for local border traffic will be banned from 17 March 2020.  
This prohibition will not apply:
- to the carriage of goods
- to nationals of the Republic of Latvia who wish to return to Latvia
- to foreign nationals whose permanent place of residence is in Latvia and who want to return here 
- to foreign nationals who want to leave Latvia.

description:
Latvia
June 2nd, 2020

The Latvian government announced on Tuesday, June 2, 2020, that it would ease restrictions on those arriving from most European countries from Wednesday, June 3, 2020. Most visitors will no longer be required to self-isolate as part of an easing of emergency coronavirus disease (COVID-19) measures. Those arriving who have been in Sweden, the UK, Portugal, Belgium, Malta, Ireland, or Spain over the past two weeks will still be required to isolate. Travel to and from all other European countries will be unrestricted.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings

description:
Latvia
June 9th 2020
"With regard to travel, the Ministry of Health calls for a careful assessment of the necessity. It must be taken into account that when abroad there is not only a higher risk of becoming infected with Covid-19, but also the risk of being quarantined and having to observe that quarantine in the specific country. At the same time, it must be borne in mind that the external border of the EU is not currently open for travel, meaning that travel to third countries is not possible. Travel is also not possible to those EU and EEA countries which are published on the SPKC website as countries with a high risk to public health (a 14-day cumulative number of Covid-19 cases that exceeds 25 per 100,000 inhabitants) and, upon entering Latvia from a country where the 14-day cumulative number of Covid-19 cases per 100,000 inhabitants exceeds 15, 14-day self-isolation will have to be observed from the day of leaving that country."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
From July 12, 2021, travelers entering Latvia from Russia and Belarus will be tested for Covid-19 at four border crossings- "Grebneva", "Terehova", "Pāternieki", and "Silene". People who have carried out the Covid-19 test at the crossing point will also await the result on the territory of that site. They will be able to leave the territory of the border crossing point only after the presentation of the results of the Covid-19 test to the State Border Guard and after the permit is given. 

People who can show a valid Covid-19 certificate of vaccination, disease meant, or Covid-19 test, as well as children under 12 years of age, are exempt from taking the test.

In case the Covid-19 test is positive or if the person refuses to take the test, the Emergency Medical Service will take the person to the tourist accommodation for mandatory isolation.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Latvia
May 27th 2020
Estonia and Latvia are reportedly among the first countries to launch smartphone apps tracing coronavirus (COVID-19) infections based on code developed by US tech giants Apple and Google.

Using smartphones to help trace coronavirus infections is considered one of the ways to curb the spread of the pandemic. Tracings apps are hoped to allow identification and fast isolating of people suspected of carrying the virus and testing those who might have been in contact with them.

description:
Latvia 
February 16th 2021
Improved testing policies will focus on large-scale, targeted and regular community screening, ensuring early detection and early control of communicable diseases. Such an approach would increase the chances of gradually reducing restrictive measures and expanding the availability of services while controlling the spread of the virus

In order to implement regular and extensive public screening, it is planned to further improve the availability of testing throughout Latvia and, in addition to the existing Covid-19 analysis transfer points, to expand off-site testing and the involvement of GPs. Covid-19 tests will be more widely available on weekends.

Also, with the emergence of new strains of Covid-19, it is planned to increase the amount of sequencing, which allows constant monitoring of virus variability or mutation detection. This is an important step in the timely detection and prevention of the spread of new strains of the virus in society.

description:

"Those who have received positive test results are encouraged to act responsibly ( https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/covid-19-pacientiem ) and immediately identify and inform potential contacts so that people can take appropriate action and observe them as soon as possible. security measures specified for contact persons ( https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/majas-karantina-kontaktpersonam ). We remind you once again that employers and family doctors, who receive information about a positive patient on the E-health portal, also inform about the status of a contact person.

People who are severely isolated at home with Covid-19 infection are encouraged to monitor their health and contact their family doctor regularly. If shortness of breath occurs, call NMPD immediately and seek immediate help 113.

The Stop Covid app can help you find out sooner that you have been in contact with a Covid-19 patient. By using the app, you can isolate yourself earlier so as not to endanger your family, colleagues, friends and the rest of the population. The app also allows patients to inform contacts who are also using Stop Covid, thus working together to reduce the chance of the infection spreading."

description:
Latvia
December 1st 2020
To date, none of the vaccine manufacturers who have reported on their vaccine research have registered Covid-19 vaccines. However, the Ministry of Health and the responsible authorities are preparing for the vaccine to be registered and available. To date, the National Health Service has entered into vaccine supply agreements with four vaccine manufacturers - AstraZeneca , Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) , BioNTech / Pfizer , CureVac . The need to contract with several vaccine manufacturers is due to the fact that it is currently not possible to predict whether the registration process for all vaccines will be successful. It is also not possible to determine which vaccines will be the most effective, efficient and safe, and it is not known exactly which vaccines will be available the fastest. The volume of vaccines offered by the four vaccine manufacturers could provide an opportunity to vaccinate approximately one million Latvians.

The European Commission recommends that, depending on the situation in each country, priority groups for people to be vaccinated could be considered. Consequently, the Ministry of Health has determined that the vaccines would be given first to health care workers, then to social care center clients and staff, and then to people over the age of 60, people with chronic illnesses, emergency department staff and educational staff. Additional information on the efficacy, effectiveness and properties of vaccines, such as unsuitabil

description:
Latvia
December 28th 2020
Vaccines contain substances, or agents, that stimulate the body’s immunity. There are different types of vaccines. Some vaccines contain weakened or killed versions of certain viruses, bacteria, or their parts. Other vaccines contain a messenger (meaning that it merely holds information about the virus and is not the virus itself, so it cannot cause the disease or make it worse if you already have it). When a person is given the vaccine, the body’s immune system makes antibodies. When a person is exposed to a real infectious virus or bacterium, their immune system remembers it. It activates specific antibodies that have already been made, kills the virus or bacteria, and does not make you sick.
How is a vaccine developed and registered?
In order to be used in the European Union, a vaccine must meet the same standards of proof of safety, quality, and effectiveness as any other medicine. No exceptions from these essential requirements are made. More than 200 Covid-19 vaccines are currently being developed worldwide, but some are already close to the final stage.

The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is the first to complete this registration process. The next known vaccines that are coming close to the final stage, at which the European Medicines Agency can decide on their registration, are those developed by AstraZeneca and Moderna.

The process of developing and registering these vaccines is faster than for other vaccines, due to the investment and pooling of
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Latvia
January 28th 2021
It is planned to vaccinate up to 70% of the Latvian population by the end of the summer, according to the informative report of the Ministry of Health "On the Covid-19 vaccination plan", which was heard today by the Cabinet of Ministers.

Minister of Health Daniels Pavļuts: “The vaccination plan we approved in government today is detailed, digital and flexible. Uncertainty is the only certainty of the time, now we will be ready to act in different situations. Both when there is a delay in the supply of vaccines and when there are a lot of them. ”

The updated vaccination plan is designed to make optimal use of the resources of the vaccination system and to implement a convenient and flexible vaccination process. The plan sets out a number of basic principles:

    the establishment of common lists of vaccinees, which will make it possible to maintain contact between those who have expressed an interest in vaccination and the location of the population in the priority group, as well as vaccination sites,
    the creation of a common calendar and queue to help plan the workload and opening hours of vaccination points and the management of records,
    centralized supply of vaccines and stockpile management,
    unified communication with the population.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Latvia
February 4th 2021
In accordance with the vaccination plan against Covid-19 approved in Latvia, the Covid-19 vaccine early application website www.manavakcina.lv has been created, which will be opened to the public on Friday, February 5, at 10.00. The goal of early application is to effectively plan the workload and capacity of vaccination rooms. Citizens are encouraged not to rush to register their applications during the first days of operation of the site. The first vaccines will be given to those in the priority groups. All other citizens' applications received within one calendar month will be treated equally, on a random basis.

description:
Latvia
February 4th 2021
In accordance with the vaccination plan against Covid-19 approved in Latvia, the Covid-19 vaccine early application website www.manavakcina.lv has been created, which will be opened to the public on Friday, February 5, at 10.00. The goal of early application is to effectively plan the workload and capacity of vaccination rooms. Citizens are encouraged not to rush to register their applications during the first days of operation of the site. The first vaccines will be given to those in the priority groups. All other citizens' applications received within one calendar month will be treated equally, on a random basis. UPDATE: Whereas prior a website and hotline were created, now, on the 18th of February 2021, GPs are joining the Covid-19 vaccination process.

The Ministry of Health invites all residents over the age of 70 who want to be vaccinated against Covid-19, but have not yet applied for their vaccine at www.manavakcina.lv or by calling 8989, to contact their family doctor now.

If the family doctor is also a provider of vaccination services (the family doctor will be able to tell you during the interview), then the family doctor will register for the vaccine, as well as the vaccination process will take place there at the GP's invitation.

If, after calling a family doctor, a resident finds out that his or her family doctor is not a vaccination service provider , then:

    some general practitioners will register, but will pass on information on applications for the organization of the vaccination process;
    other family doctors will invite residents over the age of 70 to call the free vaccination registration phone number 8989 or, if possible, register at www.manavakcina.lv;
    in both cases, the data will be used to contact the population and at some point invite the population to be vaccinated as close as possible to the territory indicated by the population.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

In accordance with the vaccination plan against Covid-19 approved in Latvia, the Covid-19 vaccine early application website www.manavakcina.lv has been created, which will be opened to the public on Friday, February 5, at 10.00. UPDATE: Whereas on the 10th of February 2021 a call line was set up, From march 1st [2021] on the telephone lines will... further increase this number, when the population will be served by 60 people at a time.

Applying for the Covid-19 vaccine on the toll-free 8989 hotline began on February 10th. The opening hours for the 8989 telephone line have also been changed. From now on, the 8989 telephone line will be open every working day from 8:00 to 20:00 , and you will also be able to register for the vaccination on weekends from 9:00 to 17:00.

description:
Latvia
February 4th 2021
In accordance with the vaccination plan against Covid-19 approved in Latvia, the Covid-19 vaccine early application website www.manavakcina.lv has been created, which will be opened to the public on Friday, February 5, at 10.00. The goal of early application is to effectively plan the workload and capacity of vaccination rooms. Citizens are encouraged not to rush to register their applications during the first days of operation of the site. The first vaccines will be given to those in the priority groups. All other citizens' applications received within one calendar month will be treated equally, on a random basis. UPDATE: Where as through out the month of February 2021 four processes to register for the vaccine were enacted; website, hotline, general practitioner, individual healthcare facilities, now on the 25th of February 2021 the government of Latvia creates a uniform procedure for vaccinations, In order to ensure a uniform and clear procedure for organizing the vaccination of the population, the Minister of Health Daniels Pavļuts has signed an order, which is binding on all medical institutions that will provide vaccination.

The procedure developed by the Ministry of Health determines the conditions for creating a record for group vaccination and primary vaccination (receipt of the 2nd dose of vaccine) in vaccination institutions and GP practices.

The procedure stipulates that medical institutions will provide vaccinations for residents who have registered with manavakcina.lv and by phone 8989, as well as vaccinations for residents who have individually applied to medical institutions, including GP practices that will not provide vaccination. In such cases, the GP will compile a list of people to be vaccinated and send it to the vaccination institution with which the practice contract has been concluded.

When making the record, GPs should, as far as possible, take into account the age and health status of the vaccinees, giving priority to the elderly or people with more severe chronic diseases, depending on the priority group to be vaccinated.

It is also stipulated that when creating a vaccination record, vaccination is provided as a priority to the population who are scheduled for primary vaccination or who are in the highest priority vaccination group.

Vaccination for patients who require serious medical manipulation as determined by a doctor, including high-cost or high-complexity surgery (eg oncology patients, before or during chemotherapy, patients and donors before organ or stem cell transplantation, long-term inpatient care) ) will be performed in a medical institution according to a doctor’s referral.

In order to prevent the loss of vaccine doses, it is envisaged that the vaccination institution will establish reserve lists of vaccinees from the current group of the population to be vaccinated as a priority or the next group to be vaccinated as a priority. This will allow for the prompt replacement of vaccinees in the event that someone does not arrive. If, at the end of the day of vaccination, there is still a stockpile of unused doses of vaccine in the vaccination establishment that cannot be maintained for the next day, it is permissible to vaccinate people outside the specified priority vaccination group. At the same time, the number of people in the vial should not exceed the number of doses and such vaccination should be documented and justified. Doses written off that have not been vaccinated by the end of the day should also be documented and justified.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Latvia
April 18th 2021

This weekend, in seven Latvian cities - Riga, Daugavpils, Liepaja, Rezekne, Jelgava, Jurmala and Cesis, everyone who wants it will have the opportunity to get vaccinated. Vaccination will be carried out with the manufacturer's AstraZeneca vaccines, and the public will be able to receive the vaccine on arrival at large-scale vaccination centers in the city.

Citizens who belong to one of the already opened priority groups will be invited to a special line for them, no additional proof of compliance with the priority group will be required. A special line at the specific location will allow you to receive the vaccine more quickly than other people who want to be vaccinated. Other people who want to be vaccinated will be directed to the second line. Vaccinations will have a pre-determined amount of vaccine in each city. Once the vaccines have been used up, the vaccination center will close on that day.

Vaccination in these cities will take place from 9:00 to 17:00 (Kipsala Hall in Riga and GORS in Rezekne until 19:00) according to the following plan:
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Latvia
February 4th 2021
In accordance with the vaccination plan against Covid-19 approved in Latvia, the Covid-19 vaccine early application website www.manavakcina.lv has been created, which will be opened to the public on Friday, February 5, at 10.00. The goal of early application is to effectively plan the workload and capacity of vaccination rooms. Citizens are encouraged not to rush to register their applications during the first days of operation of the site. The first vaccines will be given to those in the priority groups. All other citizens' applications received within one calendar month will be treated equally, on a random basis. UPDATE: On February 5th 2021 Latvia created its first webportal for aiding in citizens to become vaccinated, now on the 19th of April 202, The improved has started working today manavakcina.lv portal . It is now possible not only to apply for the vaccine, but also to choose the place and time of vaccination from open priority groups. Currently, the new website is in test mode, but gradually on the website manavakcina.lv an extensive calendar of vaccination institutions will be opened . As a result, ViVaT (Unified Vaccination Network) has started working today. ViVaT is an IT system that coordinates the calendars of Covid-19 vaccinators, records the fact of vaccination, as well as maintains the current vaccination status of the population and compliance with the priority groups.

Until now, the vaccination process has been organized manually, so additional human resources have been used to compile lists, call and coordinate records. In a short time, the unified vaccination network ViVaT and the improved have been developed manavakcina.lv website , where every inhabitant of Latvia whose vaccination priority group is open can choose both the place and time of vaccination.

description:
Latvia
March 12th 2020
Passengers initially arriving from virus affected territories and from 12
March from any country are obligated to self-quarantine for 14 days. UPDATE: Whereas prior, where those who test positive on entry should go to quarantine, now the rules are made clear, as of March 17th 2021, those who test positive on entry must isolate in a hotel with 80% of the housing and food covered.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From June 16, 2021, the requirement to self-isolate for 10 days when entering Latvia will be lifted if an individual can present a digital Covid-19 certificate confirming the completion of vaccination or recovery from the disease during the last six months. The requirement to self-isolate will remain for vaccinated/recovered people only when traveling from countries with a particularly high risk to public health (Emergency brake regulation: very high-risk country or new covid-19 variant). Also, children under the age of 12 should follow the same rules of self-isolation as their companions. Therefore, children do not need to self-isolate if a person accompanying the child does not have to. However, for 10 days after entry, those children will not be allowed to contact people outside their household, attend public events, children’s groups, go camping, school, or kindergarten, or use public transport.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry),People who have recovered and/or survived COVID-19,People who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19

description: On the 15th of June, 2021, the requirement to self-isolate for 10 days for people entering Latvia from abroad was eased. Now, people do not need to self-isolate if an individual can present a digital Covid-19 certificate confirming the completion of vaccination or recovery from the disease during the last six months. However, the requirement to self-isolate will be in place for vaccinated/recovered people if they are traveling from countries with a particularly high risk to public health (Emergency brake regulation: very high-risk country or new covid-19 variant). Also, children under the age of 12 do not need to self-isolate if a person accompanying the child does not have to. However, for 10 days after entry, those children will not be allowed to contact people outside their household, attend public events, children’s groups, go camping, school, or kindergarten, or use public transport. UPDATE: The original quarantine applied to all people entering Latvia, it has been amended so that the requirement to self-isolate when entering Latvia will be lifted if an individual can present a digital Covid-19 certificate confirming the completion of vaccination or recovery from the disease during the last six months. The requirement to self-isolate will remain for vaccinated/recovered people only when traveling from countries with a particularly high risk to public health (Emergency brake regulation: very high-risk country or new covid-19 variant). Also, children under the age of 12 should follow the same rules of self-isolation as their companions.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Latvia closes all non essential businesses from March 13. This includes: 
Nightclubs, entertainment centres, fitness clubs. Some restaurants and bars are open (e.g. take away). Shopping malls are closed. Exceptions are: food shops, press kiosks, pharmacies (incl. veterinary pharmacies), vaccination cabinets, opticians, pet food, dry cleaners, hygiene and household stores, building and garden supply stores.

Latvia
May 12th 2020
Minister of Culture implements guidelines for how Car-cinemas and Car-concerts should proceed, which include:
Cars being 2m apart
No leaving the car
One household per car

description:
Latvia closes all non essential businesses from March 13. This includes: 
Nightclubs, entertainment centres, fitness clubs. Some restaurants and bars are open (e.g. take away). Shopping malls are closed. Exceptions are: food shops, press kiosks, pharmacies (incl. veterinary pharmacies), vaccination cabinets, opticians, pet food, dry cleaners, hygiene and household stores, building and garden supply stores. UPDATE: Whereas on March 14th 2020 All non-essential establishments were closed, now "Gatherings of up to 25 people will be permitted from Tuesday, May 12 [2020], providing that individuals keep two meters apart, and all indoor events will be restricted to a maximum of three hours. Libraries, museums, and national archives, as well as concert halls and cinemas... provided "sanitary protocols" are in place. The covering of noses and mouths remain compulsory on public transport, while leisure and entertainment venues, including restaurants, will be allowed to open between 07:00 - 00:00 (local time)."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Retail Businesses

description:
Latvia
May 12th 2020
Minister of Culture implements guidelines for how Car-cinemas and Car-concerts should proceed, which include:
Cars being 2m apart
No leaving the car
One household per car
Only allowed to open windows to ventilate
There is a time limit of 6:30 to 24:00 UPDATE: Whereas on May 12th 2020, The culture minister allowed for car-cinemas or concerts to take place as long as they follow guidelines, now on the 22nd of may 2020, the culture minister expanded the rules to allow for windows to be opened for ventilation and receiving food.

As of June 9, the government of Latvia issued rules and restrictions for the food service industry to continue operations, including requiring table disinfection after each visitor's meal, having no more than 4 visitors who are not members of the same household indoors at one table, 
having no more than 8 visitors who are not members of the same household at one table outdoors,  distance of two meters between the tables is observed, if there is no partition wall between them, and hours between 6:30-2:00.

description:
Latvia
June 9th 2020
"trading and public catering places, museums, exhibitions, and nature trails... In these places... the obligation to ensure an area of 4 m2 per person. 
There are additional conditions for public catering places: a distance of 2 metres must be ensured between the tables. Until 1 July, no more than 4 persons can sit at one table indoors and no more than 8 people at one table outdoors (for example, on terraces). 
As before, cultural, sports, entertainment, and religious places may start working no earlier than 6.30 and close no later than 24.00. Open-air cinemas and public catering places are an exception, as they must close no later than 2.00 a.m."

description:
Latvia
August 17th 2020
New Corona regulations for cultural sites:
50% of the total possible number of people 
Infrastructure of the event or cultural service 3 m² area 
publicly available information on the maximum number of people allowed 
separate the flows of the groups of people present, not exceeding 300 people in each group; if achieved more than 50% can attend

If venue allows more than 500, precautionary measures must be drawn prior to event

Visitors of cultural sites will be able to sit together for two if they are not members of the same household; members of one household will be able to sit in a group of no more than four people.

Distance of 1 meter or the installation of a protective barrier between each of the two filled seating groups.
When leaving their seats, visitors to the event will have to continue to cover a distance of 2 meters.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Latvia
September 2nd 2020
in order to ensure the continuity of sports work, the Ministry of Education and Science proposed to establish an exception for athletes of the Latvian adult team, Latvian Olympic team, Latvian Paralympic team, as well as Latvian teams participating in international leagues in Olympic, Paralympic and technical sports and disciplines. When staying outside Latvia for more than three days, athletes will be required to present a document on laboratory testing for Covid-19 diagnostics no earlier than three days prior to arrival in Latvia, and it must be negative. Also, a laboratory examination for the diagnosis of Covid-19 will have to be performed within 24 hours after returning to Latvia. Even if this test is negative, athletes and sports staff will be able to continue the training process and participate in the competition, observing the prescribed precautions (including measuring body temperature for 14 days in the morning and evening; staying only in places related to the sports process, etc.), as also performing another laboratory test for Covid-19 diagnostics on day 5-7.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description:
Latvia 
October 26th 2020
The Latvian government has decided that from October 26 to November 15, places related to indoor children's entertainment (entertainment and amusement centers, children's playrooms, trampoline parks and childcare rooms, including shopping centers) are closed (do not provide services) due to rapid increase in the spread of Covid-19 in Latvia.

description:
Latvia
November 9th, 2020
Under the second state of emergency announced by the Latvian government, measures are as follows: 
On-site public events (e.g. theaters, concerts, cinema screenings) are completely banned. Swimming pools, water parks, saunas and spas must close their doors. There will be no public sports events - competitions, demonstrations, shows, etc. Catering establishments may serve food only for pick-up, except in educational institutions, workplaces and at Riga Airport.. On weekends and public holidays, only certain retailers will be allowed to open. hopping centers will open only grocery stores, pharmacies, veterinary pharmacies, animal feed stores, bookstores, press outlets, opticians, hygiene and household goods stores and telecommunications goods service points.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Retail Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Latvia
November 30th 2020
The Ministry reminds that as of November 30, 2020, parents have the opportunity to apply for sickness care allowance if the child is not allowed to attend pre-school due to circumstances related to Covid-19 infection or if the education in the general education program takes place remotely. Parents are entitled to sickness benefit for a child under 10 years of age.

description:
Latvia
December 3rd 2020
15 square meters per visitor must be provided in shops and service points. Information on the number of people allowed must be clearly visible at the entrance. In small rooms, visitors can go one by one.

Continuation of shops enforcing mask mandates

"...only pharmacies, including veterinary pharmacies, may operate on Saturdays, Sundays, and public holidays, while only groceries (except alcohol and cigarettes), hygiene products and fuel may be sold in shops."

"On weekdays, everyone works with the same quadrature constraints. On Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays, sales points may not be open, except - pharmacies (including veterinary) and shops selling food (except alcohol and cigarettes), hygiene products, fuel."

Subject to epidemiological safety measures, beauty care providers - hairdressing and manicure service providers - may operate.
